Award.AwardTitle: Change at the Core: A Collaborative Model for Undergraduate STEM Education Reform

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Change at the Core (C-Core) is a multi-disciplinary, inter-institutional project that is transforming undergraduate STEM education at Western Washington University (WWU), Whatcom Community College (WCC), and Skagit Valley College (SVC). C-Core is improving student engagement, learning, and success in STEM by creating a critical mass of STEM faculty at each institution and in each STEM department who understand and regularly use evidence-based teaching and learning practices. Participants include faculty members, department chairs, deans, and teaching assistants, who are becoming agents of change.

To achieve project goals, participants and project staff are creating a shared vision and model for transforming undergraduate STEM education. This model includes Summer Institutes on evidence-based practices, followed by professional learning communities (PLCs) to support implementation over the academic year. Institutes and PLCs are also focusing on implementation of strategies to promote underrepresented minority (URM) students' success in STEM. Assessment for Learning (AL) is C-Core's overarching framework, supported by student-centered strategies such as peer-learning, flipped classrooms, and authentic research experiences.

C-Core is generating new knowledge about organizational change at both two- and four-year institutions including alignment of institutional and departmental policies and practices to support student-centered learning, use of PLCs and change agents to create a critical mass of faculty using evidence-based practices, promotion of positive and lasting changes in faculty practices and beliefs, and improvement of URM student success and interest in STEM courses, majors, and careers. Rigorous evaluation and dissemination plans are enabling C-Core to become an adaptive model for institutional reform involving two- and four-year institutions.

To increase participation, retention and success of URM students in STEM, C-Core is partnering with high school-to-college bridge programs to recruit more URM students into STEM majors and leverage research opportunities, tutoring, and student clubs to promote academic success. Additionally, faculty are being trained to address issues of isolation, culture, and identity as ways to support URM student success in STEM. To disseminate the C-Core model regionally and nationally, WWU, WCC, and SVC are working directly with other institutions, collaborating with disciplinary-based organizations and networks such as Project Kaleidoscope (PKAL), the Science Education Resource Center (SERC), and Partnership for Undergraduate Life Sciences Education (PULSE), conducting workshops at professional society meetings, and developing a Change at the Core Webinar series.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Outcomes Report: Change at the Core: A Collaborative Model for Undergraduate STEM Education Reform

From 2014 thru 2018, the Change at the Core project brought together over 100 faculty from Skagit Valley College (SVC), Western Washington University (WWU), and Whatcom Community College (WCC) to begin the transformation to active student-centered, inclusive classrooms across all STEM disciplines. The cross-institutional approach was intended to facilitate rapid progress in improving and aligning undergraduate courses and teaching practices at the three partner institutions, as a substantial number of STEM majors at WWU begin their college careers at either SVC or WCC.

Understanding about how students learn has improved significantly over the past two decades. In 2014, Scott Freeman and others synthesized numerous prior research studies on undergraduate teaching and learning and concluded that if this was a medical clinical trial with active learning as the experimental treatment and traditional learning as the control, the experiment would be stopped and everyone given the treatment. Learning is simply more effective when students have opportunities to share their initial ideas, struggle productively with concepts, collect and make sense of data, reflect on their own understanding, and work collaboratively (Bransford, et. al., 1999). This holds true for students from all cultures, ethnicities, and age groups. In recent years there has been a concerted effort to use this knowledge to improve undergraduate teaching and learning in STEM, and many of these efforts have proved successful at the individual classroom and department levels. However, change at these levels only impacts a small number of STEM students and there was great interest in seeing if evidence-based teaching and learning experiences could be scaled up and adapted to reform multiple STEM disciplines at multiple institutions simultaneously.

At SVC, WWU, and WCC, faculty from biology, chemistry, computer science, computer information systems, engineering, environmental science, environmental studies, geology, mathematics, and physics were provided with extensive professional development on the latest research about teaching and learning. Facutly were then given time to try out new teaching and learning practices, co-develop new course activities, implement these practices and activities in their classrooms, and receive feedback from colleagues to improve their use of these practices and activities. Our hypothesis was that creating a critical mass of faculty fluent in the use of evidence-based teaching practices would lead to a within- and cross-institution culture that transforms passive, lecture-dominated STEM courses into active, student-centered learning environments.

The outcomes of Change at the Core work support this hypothesis. Outcomes include: (1) a significant shift at all three institutions, and across all STEM disciplines, toward more active, student-centered classrooms, and away from more passive, lecture-dominated classrooms, (2) changes to, and better alignment of introductory and major STEM course sequences at all three institutions, (3) creation of more inclusive and welcoming classroom and departmental/divisional environments, (4) the creation of a set of faculty "change agents" in each STEM discipline able to support other faculty in understanding and using student-centered, inclusive learning practices and helping to build a critical mass of faculty using these practices, (5) changes to college and department hiring, review, tenure, and promotion policies to promote student-centered teaching and learning, (6) increased demand for classroom spaces that support student-centered learning, and (7) impacts on faculty, administrators, and classrooms beyond STEM.

Change at the Core has also revealed that when working to reform multiple departments/divisions and institutions simultaneously, the rate of reform is likely to vary, with some STEM departments/divisions and individuals making more progress than others. This is to be expected given differences in culture, personnel, and resources to support reform efforts. Factors that positively contribute to uptake, use, and adoption of student-centered teaching and learning practices include, but are not limited to: change agents (faculty who already understand and use student-centered, inclusive learning practices and can facilitate faculty professional development); strong support, acknowledgement, and encouragement from Chairs, Deans, Provosts, and other administrators; participation of, and support for both full and part-time faculty in multi-year, professional development activities; regular classroom observations and feedback; and time to collaborate on curriculum and course reforms.

While very substantial progress has been made during the past five years to make student-centered learning the standard practice in STEM departments/divisions and courses, this is still a work in progress at all three institutions. Workshops on student-centered learning for new and part-time faculty, support from faculty change agents, adoption of new assessment practices that support faculty to continually improve their teaching, and ongoing support from administrators and colleagues will be essential for completing the transformation during the next five years.
